column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0017] The thermal substrate 308 is a planar member made of a material that supports the build material and the support material ejected from the printhead 86 and that changes color in response to heat contained within the build material or support material.
#Text=These materials increase in optical density with reference to a known function of optical density per unit of heat energy input to the material of the thermal substrate.
#Text=The areas darkened by the heat return to their original color when the heat energy dissipates.
#Text=For example, the planar substrates could be a film manufactured by LCR Hallcrest of Glenview, Ill.
#Text=See http://www.hallcrest.com/digitempsc.cfm for exemplary materials.
#Text=As used in this document, a thermal substrate is one that changes an optical density of an area on the substrate per unit of heat energy input to the area.

#Text=A reversible thermal substrate, as used in this document, refers to a thermal substrate that reverts to an optical density that an area of the substrate had prior to heat energy being input to the area.
#Text=[0018] A cleaning member 320 is mounted to a support member that is operatively connected to an actuator.
#Text=As described below, the controller 324 operates the actuator to move the support member to engage the substrate 332 with the cleaning member 320.
#Text=This action sweeps build and support material from the substrate 308 into the waste receptacle 328 to renew the surface of substrate 308 for another test pattern printing.

#Text=The cleaning member 340 can include a supply of cleaning solvent 340 that controller 324 can operate to spread cleaning solvent onto the substrate before the cleaning member sweeps the substrate.
#Text=The cleaning solvent chemically interacts with the build and support material to loosen the material before the cleaning member encounters it.
#Text=Additionally or alternatively, a heater 326 can be positioned with respect to the cleaning member 320 to heat the build and support material before the cleaning member sweeps the substrate 308.
#Text=In other embodiments, no cleaning member is provided and the controller advances the substrate 332 by an amount that enables a test pattern to be printed and then imaged with the sensor 304.
#Text=The controller 324 detects when the belt 308 is approaching one full revolution and it then generates a signal that indicates the belt 308 needs changing.
#Text=[0019] A method of operating a printer that produces three-dimensional objects is shown in FIG. 4.

#Text=In the description of this method, statements that a process is performing some task or function refers to a controller or general purpose processor executing programmed instructions stored in a memory operatively connected to the controller or processor to manipulate data or to operate one or more components in the printer to perform the task or function.
#Text=The controller 324 noted above can be such a controller or processor.

#Text=Alternatively, the controller 324 can be implemented with more than one processor and associated circuitry and components, each of which is configured to form one or more tasks or functions described herein.

#Text=[0020] At predetermined times in the printing operation, the controller 108 (FIG. 2) operates an actuator 104 to move the printhead 86 into the module 300 located in the area 112 where controller 108 operates the printhead 86 to eject build and support material onto the substrate 308, which is stationary while being printed (block 404).
#Text=In one embodiment, each inkjet in the printhead is repetitively operated to form a pile of material, also called a test dot, on a portion of the substrate 308 opposite the inkjet.
#Text=After the test pattern is printed, controller 108 generates a signal to controller 324 that indicates the material ejections forming a test pattern are completed (block 408).
#Text=In response to the signal from controller 108, controller 324 operates the optical sensor 304 to generate image data of the substrate 308 (block 420).

#Text=The operation of the sensor 304 occurs almost immediately after the test pattern is printed since the heat of the ejected material and its effect on the substrate 332 begins to dissipate as the material leaves the inkjets.

#Text=The electrical signals generated by the sensor 304 are image data that are analyzed with reference to expected positions for the build and support material used to form the test pattern to identify inoperative inkjets (block 424) and, if inoperative inkjets are identified, a signal indicative of the defective printhead is generated for the operator of the printer (block 428).
#Text=The operator can then take appropriate action.
#Text=The controller 324 continues to operate the actuator 316 to rotate the substrate 308 to prepare a clean portion for a next inkjet test (block 430).

#Text=As explained above, the cleaning can be performed by engaging the substrate 308 with the cleaning member 320 to remove material from the substrate as the substrate moves past the cleaning member or by advancing the substrate to provide a clean portion of the substrate for the next test pattern.

#Text=If material is removed by the member 320, it is collected in the waste receptacle 328, which can be removed from the printer from time to time and either replaced or emptied and then re-installed.

#Text=[0021] While the embodiments discussed above are within a printer that forms three-dimensional objects, thermal substrates and the system that detects inoperative inkjets from the effects that the heat of the ejected material has on such substrates can also be used in two dimensional document printing systems, particularly those that use clear inks.
#Text=In such systems, a thermal substrate, from time to time, passes by the printhead to be printed, imaged, and analyzed to identify inoperative inkjets.
#Text=Likewise, printheads ejecting clear ink onto a moving web or an imaging member, such as a drum, can be moved opposite a thermal substrate for printing and detection of inoperative inkjets.
#Text=Thus, as used in this document, the word "material" refers to substances that can be used to form three-dimensional objects as well as inks used in document printing.
